comments.commentBody: As a message of peace, I would recommend that the citizens of South Carolina permanently remove the Confederate flag from state and local government property  That flag sends the wrong message.  I speak as a white Southerner.

I wish the kind of people from Emmanuel AME Church who had such a dignified response to this heinous crime had had the upper hand after 9/11. I think we would be living a different story right now in America. The unbelievable response to forgive this young hater is mind-boggling. I could not do that after a crime like that. But it shows a tremendous faith in their faith itself. Amazing people there.

She can't give a straight answer because she is not a straight person The fact that she's still taken seriously by the portion of the electorate that still does means that a lot of people can't see or think straight. A perfect match!
And what is Joe Biden'so position on TPP and TPA?

After all this time, it is disappointing-- if not especially surprising-- that Hillary Clinton still finds it hard to give a straight answer on what she does and doesn't support. Once again, the listening tours, the maybes and the hedged positions grow wearisome, especially in contrast to Bernie Sanders' forthrightness.

One more thing: Democrats and Americans would be very lucky if Joe Biden decided to seek the presidency. This accomplished and decent man is exceptionally well-prepared to be president and would be ready to lead on day one.

Prejudice is always destructive and small-minded.  There is no reason to paint Charleston residents with the same brush as for Dylann Roof.  Racism, institutional and individual, most unfortunately exists nationally, not only in this region, so boycotting local businesses in South Carolina will not help foster inclusive thinking.  I saw so much beauty from Charleston citizens in the wake of the mass murder -  black and white hands interlocked, affirming that hate will not win.  We all need more room for affinity and less knee-jerk rejection of a place and its people.

Lowering the deficit only requires that government income less government spending is a smaller negative number.  If the ACA, which mandates increased taxes,  pays out less in subsidies and other payments than it collects in fines and taxes, it lowers  the deficit.   Nonetheless, lowering the deficit doesn't necessarily mean that payouts are reduced since as long as they are more than offset by increases in government collections, benefit payments  can actually increase at the same time as the net effect is a reduction of the deficit.

Although I think the Confederate flag should never fly at a public building anywhere, the flag, itself is not the problem. It is the attitude of the people who insist on flying the flag. I have lived in the South all my life. My great-grandfather was a Confederate soldier from West Virginia. Despite that, he never held any animosity towards African Americans or Union soldiers.  He never flew the Confederate flag, nor did any of his descendants. We accept that the war has been over for a very long time and that the Confederates lost. Anytime a misguided person perpetrates violence against another for any reason, especially racism, we as a country lose a little piece of our soul. The reaction of the AME church is remarkable and I wish we could all show forgiveness as they have. If we did we would live in a very different world.

The Confederate flag is still given a place of prominence on the Capitol grounds in Columbia and that's all there is to it. You can sugar coat it anyway you want.

I would like to think if I were in Columbia following the murders in Charleston I would have physically removed that flag.

From all reports, the flag was less conspicuous high atop the dome of the capitol than it is now at more of a street level. The extensive debate only moved the flag at few feet rather than eliminating it altogether as it should have.

I know it is a distinction that is lost on many people, but the Confederate flag has not flown over the capitol building of South Carolina for several years, contrary to what has been reported in New York Times articles and written by several readers.  It was previously removed by legislative action from atop the State House and a smaller banner flies over a memorial to Confederate soldiers on the State House grounds.  I'm not defending the flag or what it symbolizes.  I'm merely pointing out that there has already been extensive debate in South Carolina regarding the Confederate flag.  As a result,  where it now flies is not where it historically flew, and its current location is less prominent than its previous location.

Charleston has voted Democrat in the last two elections.  If you want to make a statement about right wing extremism, you would be wiser to stop visiting Myrtle Beach, which overwhelmingly votes Republican.

Yes Charleston has had the same Democratic mayor, Joseph P. Riley Jr., for seemingly decades now but it is only one piece in the puzzle that is South Carolina.  That horrible flag flies over the Capitol of the entire state and should have come down long ago.  Charleston is the most backward looking city of any southern city today....they celebrate the past that included a live slave market in its midst.

They are not,"celebrating" the past anymore than the Holocaust Museum is "celebrating" the death camps. History is history and should be on display for all to see. I just wish the history of Jim Crow and the Civil Rights movement were on display more and that people understood the horrors of that time.  I grew up in the South and saw the separate water fountains and restrooms, the separate waiting rooms at the bus and train stations, the whites only first floor of the movie theaters. I saw the television reports of Bull Connor turning  the fire hoses on African Americans, of the bombing of the church in Birmingham that killed three little African American girls, of,the murder of three Civil Rights workers slain because they were trying to register African American voters. It was a violent time and those of us who didn't live it seem to have little knowledge of the time and definitely don't know the emotions tied to it. Would you wish that the African Americans turn to anger rather than forgiveness? If so, you don't understand MLK Jr and all that he sacrificed for civil rights.

Terrible time for South Carolina and my heart goes to all of its people. Charleston used to be my family's preferred fall destination, but... we intent to take our tourist dollars elsewhere until the Confederate flag flies no more. We will not be supporting bigotry.

'it is weird to see how VSP analyze the position of Varoufakis as playing a game of chicken in the negatiations, just because he has been teaching game theory.'

And what is very annoying fot other Europeans who are in the same position as Greece -(being 'broke) - that the Greek politicians play it in such a... lets call it 'counterproductive' way - as alsmost everybody in Europe knows too - that 'the rich' have and WILL pay for the poorer nations. -(as they always did in the last 5 years)

BUT you don't rub in - in such a stupid and arrogant way - that the people who are even 'poorer' than the Greece say: Wait a minute - why do these guys get all the dough and we have to be moderate?

It is most likely that the answer means that Greeks really prefer to remain within the European Union.
In a similar point, it is weird to see how VSP analyze the position of Varoufakis as playing a game of chicken in the negatiations, just because he has been teaching game theory. In that way, it is easier to discount the fact that he is sincere in defending the Greek people against a VSP-inducad austerity.

If you were to ask a different question - what is the difference between Iceland and Greece? What is the difference between a successful recovery from a debt induced banking crisis pushing a small nation towards the brink and a failure to recover?

In this case it is your own currency that moderates the impact on local wages and exports to start with. The second thing is a debt haircut. The icelanders were very brave or naughty depending on your point of view and stuck it to the banks directly by repudiating the debt.

Thirdly the icelanders were able to fall back on their own sense of community and the resources that they have been able to hang on to - fish stocks, geothermal energy and tourism.

All of these options are still available to greece. Yet I fear the Greeks are different culturally to the Icelanders. 2000 years of being traders and middlemen in the Roman, Byzantine and Ottoman empires means that it may be difficult to strike out on your own and leave the latest EU empire.

Don't believe the rubbish spouted about Greeks being only able to make olive oil. Give the Greek people their own currency and decent mercantile govt and they will create export sectors out of thin air. The Russian oil pipeline may be the start of one already.

As a New Zealander I can still recall people saying New Zealanders can't make wine, our climate isn't suitable. Now it is a billion dollar export sector for NZ and we have some of the best Sauvignion Blancs and Pinot Noirs in the world.

A heart patient goes to his cardiologist for his 6 month ECG. the doctor bills $326.00. The doctor's office is sold to a hospital. The same patient comes in to the same doctor's office and and his ECG is $1625. Why? Because the outpatient procedure is now an inpatient procedure and the latter earns a higher payment.
This article interested me because this shows that doctors are trying to find ways to treat these heart attacks.  I think this is great news to know that death rates are decreasing.

Never allow the label to convince you of what a tax does and does not do. A VAT is imposed on services unless designed not to tax services. A VAT can be imposed by only taxing a business' profits and labor costs. This is called the additive method. Most countries use the credit method and that too can tax services unless excluded law. For example, the last time I looked, in the UK most services, including accounting and legal services are subject to VAT.

Surprisingly, under the original Civil War version of the U.S. income tax, renters were allowed a personal deduction for their rent and interest and state and local taxes were also deductible thereby putting homeowners and renters on the same foot. In the early 1870s that income tax was repealed and subsequent iterations of the income tax did not allow a deduction for rent of housing. Your position that a VAT is therefore superior to an income tax is wrong. As I started out saying, to understand what a given tax does and does not tax, you have to examine all of its provisions. Labels and generalities are not enough. Congress could easily put renters and home owners on the same footing if it wished to so design the tax that way. But, do not count on it happening. Home owners likely vote in much greater numbers and are more vocal than renters. Moreover, making up for the revenue that would be lost by a renter's deduction would prove to be an impossible task in the present political environment.

I will say that sometimes these urgent care places provide superior care or advice.  My son had symptoms of DVT after an 18-hour flight from Asia.  The RN available on call-in told us to go immediately  to a hospital.  They kept him in the waiting room for hours, futzed around with some basic blood tests. Did a chest xray and had him sit.  When we finally saw a PA he rushed around getting the right blood test stat.  My son ended up fine but my RN sisters were incredulous. Had he really developed the condition in flight and sat around like he did he could have had an embolism break.

Independent:

As I see it, we have not really addressed the effects of globalization and technology on our system. Both parties tried the "usual suspects" -- ex., tax cuts, stimulus spending -- but neither was successful.

Focusing on growth and creating middle class jobs, versus just a bigger safety net, is the preferable answer, in my view.

The road to reducing inequality leads directly through businesses, big and small. Getting big business, especially, to do more for American workers, and to do more in this country, in general, will require incentives (ex., reductions in corporate taxes for big businesses, regulatory burdens for small businesses, etc.) There's been no engagement.

It is why a republican interested in jobs and growth is the what we need right now, in my view. Enough federal government-centric solutions. The answers lie outside government, and an anti-business posture (unfortunately where the Democratic Party is right now) is not in the country's best interests.
